prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Specific factors articulated by the Panel—Pendency of at least one action in proposed transferee district

para.paratext: The Panel has always expressed a strong preference for ordering transfer only in cases where there is at least one action pending in the proposed transferee district. This factor plays an obvious and important role in selecting a transferee district if the Panel determines that transfer is appropriate;[1] it plays a lesser but nonetheless important role in determining if transfer should be ordered. The Panel's preference for a district where at least one action is pending is reflected in a case where no action is pending in the district where the defendant is located, so the Panel selects a district with a pending action that is closest to where the defendant is located.[2]

Despite the power of this factor in the ordinary course, the Panel will not hesitate to centralize cases in a completely new forum, one where no actions are pending, when it feels that action would serve the best interests of the litigation. In one important docket the Panel centralized a massive docket in a district where no actions were pending, mainly because the parties had been so parochial in their arguments for “friendly” forums that the Panel viewed their actions as attempted manipulation and forum shopping. The Panel transferred the cases to a district where a former Panel member and Chair of the Board of Editors of the Manual for Complex Litgation could preside.[3]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See In re LandAmerica 1031 Exchange Services, Inc., Internal Revenue Service § 1031 Tax Deferred Exchange Litigation, 626 F. Supp. 2d 1345 (J.P.M.L. 2009).

See In re Silicone Breast Implants Products Liability Litigation, 793 F. Supp. 1098, 1100–01 (J.P.M.L. 1992). See also In re Dial Complete Marketing Sales Practices Litigation, 804 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2011) (parties supported six other districts, but not district chosen).
